item.title: Why Tales of the Shire Is Taking a Big Risk With Its Depictions of Hobbits
item.description:
Highlights

  • Tales of the Shire offers a cozy life sim featuring Hobbits, a new take on The Lord of the Rings narrative.
  • Focusing solely on the peaceful Shire lifestyle may result in a lack of excitement for fans accustomed to Middle-earth turmoil.
  • Despite potential concerns, Tales of the Shire caters to fans of relaxing games like Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing.

The Lord of the Rings is one of the most influential fantasy franchises around, and Tales of the Shire is shining the spotlight on one of its most notable races: Hobbits. Tales of the Shire set out to bring cozy life sim gameplay to life with Hobbits in the leading role, which is a drastically new approach to The Lord of the Rings .

Whether it be in the story of The Lord of the Rings or The Hobbit , the small-statured, easy-going race that J.R.R. Tolkien dreamed up has usually led the narrative. However, the one major difference between these stories and Tales of the Shire is that the Hobbits were always embroiled in some sort of adventure or battle. Bilbo was known for his adventurous spirit, while Frodo was thrust into the middle of a monumental war between good and evil. Hobbits are known for their peaceful lifestyle, but this has rarely ever been the main focus of Tolkien's stories. Such a cozy atmosphere could prove to be a great change of pace, but it could also be too drastic.

Tales of the Shire Foregoing the Turmoil of Middle-earth

The Peaceful Life of Hobbits Could Make or Break Tales of the Shire

It's one thing to appreciate the uneventful lifestyle that Hobbits tend to enjoy, but it's a completely different thing to center an entire game around this concept. Middle-earth is a vast land that is filled with a lot of excitement, good and bad, so sticking to only the Shire could run the risk of feeling uneventful for many fans of The Lord of the Rings . Farming, fishing, and enjoying a casual stroll are wonderful things, but this could also get boring rather quickly.

The Shrine is a beautiful place, but completely ignoring the horrors of Middle-Earth only diminishes the value of the peace that Hobbits enjoy!

It's unclear what age of Middle-earth Tales of the Shire will focus on. However, there has rarely ever been complete peace in the land. Tales of the Shire ignoring the regions of Middle-earth that lie outside the Shire could diminish the game's intended tone of relaxation. It could be hard to play along with a carefree life sim when there is potential turmoil and horrors just outside of one's neighborhood. For the most part, when The Lord of the Rings showcases a Hobbit character in the past, they are presented as fish out of water. That's what makes them so compelling. Putting a small creature up against the larger-than-life forces of darkness is a powerful contrast.

Missing this aspect in Tales of the Shire may feel odd to those who are particularly passionate about The Lord of the Rings and its lore. Also, there is still the potential for the game to feel stale without the ongoing war of Middle-earth being the focus, but only time will tell.

Tales of the Shire Can Still Find Its Audience

Despite these concerns, the cozy life sim genre is still as prevalent and popular as ever. Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing have really brought relaxing, low-effort games into the spotlight in recent years, and Tales of the Shire is smart to capitalize on this. Weta Workshop's upcoming Hobbit-focused venture may not be for every fan of The Lord of the Rings , but it doesn't necessarily have to be.

Tales of the Shire is looking to appeal to fans of a certain genre, so even if the game seems dull or uneventful to those who are more invested in The Lord of the Rings and its wars, it will still find its audience. Yes, Tales of the Shire is at a much slower pace than the franchise usually goes for, but maybe that's exactly what it needs.

item.title: Best Shotguns In Call Of Duty: Modern Warfare 3, Ranked
item.description:
Highlights

  • The Bryson 800 is a reliable and customizable pump-action shotgun that offers good range and damage in Modern Warfare 3 .
  • The Expedite 12 is a semi-automatic shotgun with fast fire rate and mobility, but players need to manage its heavy recoil.
  • The Haymaker may not have high damage capabilities, but its mag-fed design allows for rapid shooting in close-range scenarios.

Shotguns remain heavy hitters, and Call of Duty : Modern Warfare 3 brings these tameable beats to the front lines of the action. The best Shotguns in Modern Warfare 3 truly depend on the individual player’s taste, since the game provides a bout of them to choose from. Players will feel like John Wick going gun-shopping with the selection available to them, but which do they prefer a fast-firing slow slug hitter or a buckshot one-tap stopper?

The selection is large, but only a few can be regarded as MW3 ’s best Shotguns. Whilst players may not be able to beat out the range of Sniper Rifles and Battle Rifles, they can certainly get far too close for comfort against their opponents, and unleash Hell onto their enemies with often a single trigger and a controlled space, allowing for domination on the battlefield.

Updated on August 7, 2024, by Jake Fillery: Hard-hitting shotguns are a powerhouse for those who play Call of Duty on the edge, seeking out enemies in close-quarter combat. The best shotguns in Modern Warfare 3 will provide players with a kicking fury, but the selection is rather limited and tame when compared to the best guns in Modern Warfare 3. Focusing purely on shotguns, players might find their new main weapon of choice before the MW3 meta changes once again.

10 KV Broadside

Fastest Firing Sem-Auto

  • How to Unlock : Reach level 55 and Activate the Challenge

Boasting of the ability to be the fastest-firing shotgun in the shotgun class for MW3, the KV Broadside is a weapon for those who like to be fast and accurate. It's always good to have a weapon that fires fast, as quick turning and domination over targets with slower weapons will always reign supreme, especially in close-quarter situations. Yet, even with a fast firing rate, the range and recoil mean that players might struggle to win out against some other shotguns found in the same class.

9 Riveter

Fully Automatic Shotgun

  • How to Unlock : Reach level 25 and Activate the Associated Challenge

Another full-auto shotgun for the collection, the Riveter is built around an assault rifle receiver, meaning that players can punch holes in any opponent who dares to cross their path. The damage is decent, and the fire rate is top-notch, allowing players to treat this weapon like a close-range machine gun that kicks and hits equally as hard. The mobility and handling excel, so this is definitely a shotgun that needs to be up close to enemies, and definitely for breaching around corners and buildings, and not for use in medium and long-range battles.

8 Bryson 890

Fast Shooting, Faster Reloading

  • How to Unlock : Reach level 55 and Activate the Challenge

With a fast reload time and a set of 24 reserve shells, the Bryson 890 may not be the best shotgun, but it certainly takes itself seriously. There's a high impact on the shotgun, allowing for an extreme burst of damage to whoever is unlucky enough to run a corner and be hit by its stopping power. It lacks in range and fire rate and somewhat falters in mobility and handling, but that is nothing compared to its potential to clear out rooms of enemies quickly.

7 Bryson 800

Great For Modifications With Close-Range & Medium-Range Focus

  • How to Unlock : Reach level 4

The Bryson 800 feels like a classic Shotgun for modern wielders. It’s everything players could want from a Shotgun, with its reliable frame, customization options, and classic pump-action design. The fire rate may be average, but the range and damage make it a durable weapon so players can use it within close or medium range. Players can enjoy the Bryson 800 as a consistently good Shotgun in Modern Warfare 3 .

6 Expedite 12

Fierce Recoil, But Fiercer Bullets

  • How to Unlock : Reach Level 55

The Expedite 12 is a practical weapon, that is, for anyone who can deal with the heavy recoil. As a semi-auto shotgun, the Expedite 12 is fast enough to take out the competition, one enemy at a time. However, players are going to want to make sure that they account for the recoil. It’s well worth fighting the recoil, as the damage, range, and mobility of the weapon allow it to devastate anyone that players are fast enough to chase down and destroy.

5 Haymaker

Rapid-Fire Shotgun For Room Clearing

  • How to Unlock : Reach Level 39

The Haymaker may not be the greatest Shotgun, but it’s more than capable in close-range scenarios. The Haymaker is unique due to the fact it has a mag-fed design, allowing players to rapidly shoot its bullets to pile into enemies. Whilst great at close range, and more than capable thanks to its rapid rate of fire for a shotgun, the Haymaker does in fact suffer from average damage statistics, meaning players might need more than one shotgun shell to pull off a kill.

4 MX Guardian

Fully Automatic With a Great Ammo Capacity

  • How to Unlock : Reach Level 55

Another high-firing Shotgun is the MX Guardian, which has a helical magazine capable of holding 15 rounds. As a fully automatic Shotgun, the MX Guardian will provide a safety net for players who might miss more shots than they are comfortable with for this Sledgehammer Games-led COD title.

The large round capacity and fully automatic design means that players can happily shoot to kill, and overindulge their trigger-happy desires. Players might need to use more than a few of these bullets due to the fact that it has lesser damage capabilities.

3 Lockwood 300

Excellent Range and Tight Pellet Spread at the Cost of Ammo

  • How to Unlock : Reach Level 55

A break-action shotgun that sacrifices its ammo capacity for range, the Lockwood 300 has a tight pellet spread, meaning that to those accurate enough, they can turn any hostile into formidable and easily destroyed prey. The extended range of the Lockwood 300 means that even with only 2 rounds in the chamber, players should be able to pull off efficient kills in this shorter campaign COD title.

However, players won’t be able to use the Lockwood 300 to take out squads, especially with the desire to reload. It hits hard, and fast, and players will need to be accurate for it to work in their favor.

Whilst the Lockwood 300 might have more of a classic look, the Lockwood 680 is more modern and even more effective and versatile. In most scenarios, Lockwood 680 can dominate thanks to its damage abilities, average fire rate, and its high accuracy and handling. The lack of recoil control leaves much to be desired, so players will need to have a practical hand to deal with the strength of this kicking weapon.

Like with most recent updates, the newer weapons are going to steal the show. The Reclaimer 18 comes as part of Season 4, and with it, mass devastation is unleashed for those seeking a shotgun with the potential to destroy entire teams. The Reclaimer 18 is one of the few shotguns that can one-shot enemies at a decent range, and the mixture of pump-action and semi-auto power makes the Reclaimer 18 a more versatile shotgun that fits the use of any player who wants to run around or cower behind corners.

item.title: Diablo 4: Of Lambs & Wolves Walkthrough
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How To Start Of Lambs And Wolves
  • How To Get Through The Reinforced Door In Season Of The Infernal Legion
  • House Of The Family Walkthrough

Seasonal quests focus on the main group you'll be working with that season, and help set up the new content the player will be seeing during that season. Season 5 in Diablo 4 is Season Of The Infernal Legions and will have players working alongside some unlikely friends to drive the forces of hell out of Sanctuary.

While the seasonal quests aren't required to see a lot of what the season has to offer, the first mission will need to be completed to unlock the seasonal reward path and start farming the new major resource of the season; Mother's Gifts. Of Lambs and Wolves also has one section with a reinforced door that may give players some trouble; here's how to complete the quest.

How To Start Of Lambs And Wolves

Of Lambs and Wolves can be started whenever you reach the season content, either by finishing the main story or by skipping it when creating a new seasonal character. Once in the new season, travel to Zarbinzet, found along the bottom of the map towards the middle .

New characters who skip the main story will be able to teleport to Zarbinzet even if they haven't been there yet.

Once in town, look to the right to see Captain Cireska talking to a man named Locran. After talking with both individuals, Locarn will invite you to visit the house southwest of town.

How To Get Through The Reinforced Door In Season Of The Infernal Legion

The house isn't hard to find, but some players may find they aren't able to interact with the door. The quickest fix to this problem is teleporting back to town and coming back to the house . Players can teleport back to town right after talking to Locran, as the game needs to register that you're progressing with the quest, and teleporting makes that happen.

You'll know the quest is ready to progress when a seasonal icon appears over the door. Should this not work, make sure you exhaust all dialogue options with Locran. If this has been done, log out and log back into the game, restarting the game too , just to be safe. After doing so, players will be able to interact with the door and talk to the person behind it to gain entry in the House Of The Family.

House Of The Family Walkthrough

After entering the house for the first time, you'll meet Istel, after which Locran will come to your defense. In the next room, you'll get an explanation of what is happening during the Season, earning Mother's Gifts, and also receiving her blessings. After Istel begins the ritual for you, be prepared for two small fights as she summons two demons individually for you to kill , but these fights are easy and can be done at even level 1.

item.title: 10 Best Dark Fantasy CRPGs, Ranked
item.description:
Highlights

  • CRPGs, inspired by Tabletop RPGs, offer players freedom in decisions and actions but vary greatly in setting, often embracing dark fantasy themes.
  • Games like Age of Decadence and Vampire: The Masquerade explore brutal realities, corruption, and moral dilemmas in dark, oppressive, and twisted worlds.
  • Titles like King Arthur: Knight's Tale and Shadowrun: Dragonfall fuse elements of dark fantasy with intense narratives, challenging players with gritty settings.

Despite not having the same frequency of major releases as in the past, CRPGs remain one of the most beloved genres among gamers, especially those who prefer PCs as their primary platform. This genre, inspired by Tabletop RPGs, offers gameplay that grants a lot of freedom to the player based on their decisions and actions, but can vary wildly in terms of setting.

Whether they're set in modern or medieval environments, many of these CRPGs also adopt elements of Dark Fantasy , presenting players with a darker and more violent story than usual. Despite the heavier tones, these games still offer incredible narratives, complex characters, and engaging challenges that captivate from beginning to end.

10 The Age Of Decadence

A Desolate Post-Apocalyptic World

As strange as it may seem, The Age of Decadence is set after the collapse of human civilization, where an ancient magical war has devastated humanity. Inspired by the esthetics of the Roman Empire, this title places players in an incredible setting where choices and actions shape a dark and decadent world, marked by the struggle for survival.

Dark fantasy is present in a striking way, with a narrative rich in political intrigue and betrayals, set in an oppressive scenario. The game stands out for its brutal realism and the absence of classic heroes, offering an experience where power corrupts, and decisions have relentless consequences. The somber setting and ambiguous morality define the essence of this unique CRPG.

9 Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines

Exploring The Dark Underworld Of Los Angeles

Although it does not use the isometric perspective that many other CRPGs do, Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines is still part of the genre and delivers a good experience for players who love Dark Fantasy stories. Here, players assume the role of a vampire in the underworld of Los Angeles.

With a dark atmosphere and interwoven elements of horror, this game explores themes of morality, power, and corruption. Players encounter supernatural creatures, engage in political intrigue, and face ethical dilemmas that challenge their humanity. Additionally, the decadent urban setting of Los Angeles enhances the game's gothic tones, making the experience immersive and intense.

8 King Arthur: Knight's Tale

A Twisted Version Of Avalon

King Arthur is one of the most classic characters in European mythology, and in King Arthur: Knight's Tale , the game presents a reimagining of his legend. Playing as Sir Mordred, Arthur's former enemy, players are brought back to life by the Lady of the Lake to face the resurrected king. Avalon, now a land of nightmares, is filled with magical creatures and hidden dangers.

Elements of dark fantasy permeate every aspect of this tactical CRPG, from complex moral choices to intense strategic battles. The setting is a dark and twisted version of Avalon, where corruption and decay are visible around every corner. The mission to destroy the immortal King Arthur and rebuild Camelot challenges players to navigate an unforgiving world full of betrayal, reinforcing the atmosphere of despair and continuous struggle.

7 Shadowrun: Dragonfall

A Fusion Of Cyberpunk And Dark Fantasy

Although not as popular as Cyberpunk 2077 , Shadowrun is a franchise that tells very good urban fantasy sci-fi stories. In Shadowrun: Dragonfall , the game mixes elements of Medieval fantasy, such as elves, orcs, and the like, with futurism. The cyberpunk setting adds a layer of complexity and darkness to the narrative, creating a dark and intriguing world.

Set in a dystopian future where magic and technology coexist, Shadowrun: Dragonfall presents a fragmented Berlin governed by stable anarchy. The story involves the rise of a new threat linked to the return of an ancient dragon, Feuerschwinge. This dark fantasy scenario explores themes of corruption, betrayal, and survival, requiring players to face dark conspiracies and difficult moral decisions in a world of decay and constant danger.

6 Tyranny

Evil Has Won, But Now What?

Avoiding the clichés of CRPGs where players are expected to be heroes, Tyranny , one of the best games made by Obisidian, places them in the role of an officer of an evil empire that has already conquered the world. The game offers a narrative where the villain has already prevailed, and the task is to manage and consolidate their dominance, dealing with the complexities of maintaining an authoritarian regime.

Dark fantasy is present in every difficult moral decision and the grim consequences that follow. Thus, the setting is unforgiving and dark, filled with betrayal, oppression, and manipulation. Black magic and sinister rituals are common, reinforcing the tense and dark atmosphere of the universe, and making each choice deepen the immersion in a world where hope is scarce and power corrupts.

5 Pathfinder: Wrath Of The Righteous

A Battle Between Humans And Demons For Power

Set in Golarion, a setting created for the Pathfinder tabletop RPG, Wrath of the Righteous presents players with a greater dark fantasy setting, especially when compared to its predecessor, Pathfinder: Kingmaker . In this CRPG by Owlcat Games, players find themselves in a hopeless world where an ancient war against demons seems lost.

In this game, even the heroes are not examples of strong moral individuals, and in the role of the protagonist, players can make various decisions that impact the world around them for better or worse. Additionally, other NPCs are equally complex, making the narrative experience of Pathfinder: Wrath of the Righteous excellent for CRPG fans.

4 Pillars Of Eternity

A Love Letter To Old CRPGS

If CRPGs are experiencing a comeback moment in the market today, much of that is due to the quality of Pillars of Eternity , which rejuvinated the genre for a new audience to experience. The story, despite having several moments of high fantasy, is still filled with desolation, frequently flirting with dark fantasy.

In the first few minutes of the game, for example, when players arrive at one of the first available locations and learn a bit more about the world's lore, they are immediately faced with a tree full of hanged bodies at the entrance. Other elements of the narrative and world-building, as well as various characters and their problems, are further indications of these dark fantasy elements.

3 Dragon Age Origins

A Grim Tale Of Betrayal And Blood Magic

Although the Dragon Age trilogy has good narratives throughout, the story of Dragon Age Origins , the first game in the franchise, is one of the darkest. From the very beginning, when players are playing through the introduction of the main character, it is plain to see that dark fantasy will be an element used throughout the narrative.

Betrayals, murders, and various other profane practices, such as blood magic, permeate the universe of Dragon Age in its entirety. Thus, amid the dilemmas faced by everyone, even morally sound characters will make questionable choices, highlighting the dark tone of the narrative. Alliances are fragile, and the threats of the corrupted world of Thedas are powerful.

2 Baldur’s Gate 3

A Game Full Of Nuance

Baldur’s Gate 3 is part of a colorful universe filled with elements of high fantasy, but upon closer inspection, the story the game tells players is full of dark fantasy elements. The first two chapters, for example, are a great demonstration of this. The main characters must deal with the desolation of being attacked by goblins and their leaders, Mindflayers, a cult, and more. All that, just to move on and have to deal with the Shadow-cursed Lands.

Moreover, for players who choose to play as the Dark Urge instead of following Tav's path, they will be met with a story full of violence, where it is necessary to either resist the protagonist's urges to avoid causing further death, or succumb to them and join Bhaal's cause. However, even players who try to follow a path of goodness with the Dark Urge will still have to deal with the dark aspects of the character.

1 Planescape: Torment

A Philosophical Journey In A World Of Desolation

One of the best narratives ever presented in a CRPG is also filled with dark fantasy elements. Planescape: Torment places players in control of the Nameless One, an immortal figure covered in scars and tattoos, with no memory of their past lives. Set in the planar city of Sigil, the game explores a world where portals lead to mysterious places, and every decision shapes the protagonist's journey.

This dark fantasy universe is highlighted by complex moral choices and interactions with unique characters, such as a chaste succubus and a floating skull. The oppressive atmosphere and philosophical themes, such as the nature of humanity and the search for redemption, permeate the entire narrative. The dark setting and deep exploration of existential questions make Planescape: Torment a captivating and unforgettable experience.

item.title: Elden Ring's Difficulty Shows FromSoftware Fans Can Have Their Cake and Eat it Too
item.description:
Highlights

  • Elden Ring's open-world design allows players to tackle challenges at their own pace, avoiding roadblock bosses.
  • The Shadow of the Erdtree DLC introduces new difficult bosses, encouraging players to try out new equipment and builds.
  • By finding a balance between accessibility and challenge, Elden Ring has become FromSoftware's most approachable game.

If there's one thing that players can almost certainly count on, it's having the conversation of difficulty in games being reignited following the release of a new FromSoftware title. Like clockwork, the release of Elden Ring 's Shadow of the Erdtree DLC almost immediately divided players on the subject of its challenge, with FromSoftware even going so far as to provide players with a helpful reminder of the importance of Shadow of the Erdtree's Scadutree fragments and a useful map to their locations. Truthfully, though, regardless of how players feel about Shadow of the Erdtree's approach to scaling and progression, there's a case to be made that Elden Ring has resolved the Soulslike difficulty debate for good.

Simply by nature of being an open-world game, Elden Ring already sidesteps one of the more common reasons players abandon FromSoftware titles – skill checks or "roadblock bosses" – by abandoning the bottleneck of its more linear titles and allowing players to explore other areas and come back to previous challenges stronger. Further, the sheer amount of weapons and equipment that players have access to (along with the ease of respec-ing using Larval Tears) means that a new build and accompanying change in strategy are never out of reach. Elden Ring and the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC prove that the flexibility FromSoftware affords players in their expression makes the difficulty discussion a bit of a moot point.

Shadow of the Erdtree Continues a FromSoftware Tradition to Appease Longtime Souls Fans

As a studio, FromSoftware has a longstanding tradition of crafting incredibly challenging DLC intended to be tackled in the late or endgame. Expansions like Bloodborne 's Old Hunters DLC or Dark Souls 3 's The Ringed City are notorious for introducing some of the hardest bosses that FromSoftware has ever devised, and Elden Ring 's Shadow of the Erdtree is no exception. While the base game of Elden Ring is home to plenty of substantial challenges in its own right, the DLC takes things a step further, introducing several new boss encounters that each hold their own alongside the likes of Orphan of Kos, Sister Friede, or Malenia, Blade of Miquella.

The new bosses in Shadow of the Erdtree are a suitable challenge for even the most skilled veteran players, while also serving as a great excuse to try out new equipment and builds introduced in the DLC. Similar to the base game of Elden Ring , Shadow of the Erdtree encourages players to experiment with various play styles and builds to overcome seemingly impossible challenges, and the ability to take a break from a boss and grind out runes to gain strength (or travel the Shadow Realm in search of Scadutree fragments) means players are never out of options when it comes to tackling a daunting boss.

FromSoftware's Next Game Will Likely Continue to Strike a Balance With its Difficulty

Between its open-world format and the ability for players to use several new combat additions to their advantage (Ashes of War, Spirit Summons, and the like), Elden Ring strikes what could be considered a delicate balance between accessibility and challenge. Make no mistake, Elden Ring is a FromSoftware game through and through, and its Shadow of the Erdtree DLC provides a suitable endgame challenge like the studio's other expansions, but it's almost surely the most approachable experience for players new to FromSoftware's unique and captivating gameplay. And Elden Ring has the sales figures to back that sentiment up.

Thanks at least in part to its accessibility, Elden Ring would achieve sales figures surpassing the entire Dark Souls trilogy in just a fraction of the time it took for that franchise to reach the same milestone. Similarly, Elden Ring 's success and welcoming of newcomers to the FromSoftware fold would crossover a bit into Armored Core 6 , which is now the best-selling game in that franchise by a large margin. Elden Ring occupies a satisfying middle ground where its difficulty is concerned, and future FromSoftware games will likely continue to follow its lead in an effort to replicate its breakthrough success.
